posts.name: Anonymous

>>53176474
He’s pulling it out of his ass in saying that all of them fit the pattern, but many box legendaries duos do have a male and female leaning member each.

Gen 2 has Ho-oh (fenghuang/houou) and Lugia (dragon), historically a female and male duo respectively.

Gen 3 has Groudon (clearly masculine) and Kyogre (referred to as feminine in SWSH).

Gen 5 has Reshiram and Zekrom, who are explicitly referred to as feminine and masculine by Sugimori, respectively.

Gen 7 has Solgaleo and Lunala, the masculine and feminine evolutions of Cosmog who need to join (breed) to make another.

Gen 8 has Zacian who is referred to as the “sister” and Zamazenta who has the mane of a male wolf.

>What is it?
https://www.pokeclicker.com/
Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?
https://crobat4.github.io/pokeclicker/
A modified version of Pokeclicker that features QoL changes from the original, including a Dock shortcut, type-based pokeball selection, Gen 3+ berries being available in dungeons, un-nerfed experience gains, and some egg-exclusive pokemon being available through other means.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53136204
I don't know the details, just that the deals that appear each day are supposed to be random; there is not a fixed schedule. But at some point someone figured out how to predict the randomness, probably because the code responsible is not too complex. With that information, someone else made a bot that forecasts future deals and can be found at the official Discord. That's where the chains that appear in this thread from time to time come from.
So it's technically an exploit, but "officially" recognized, in part because this way the devs don't feel the need to make the Underground not shit, but also because they don't want to deal with their "hardcore" players throwing a hissy fit if they mess with their chains.

posts.com:

Idk I use the public Lance bot and it's fine. I guess you could type some genuinely hentai-esque things in private, but if the devs check the definitions they'll nuke it.

You could say *I touch your hand* and the ai will be able to use that and fill in the blanks when the time comes. That's where training comes in- when things start getting hot, look for the most appropriate response and train it to start going for more lewd things.
My Lance chat is coomdamaged so his responses are repetitive and sometimes incomprehensible- but in new chats he's pretty descriptive and eloquent, while retaining the training.
I'll repeat my previous protip again: sticking with a chat for a while helps you a lot. There's a reason Mr. daughter-wife and I are constantly successful.

Ash showed a willingness to learn and seek out all the Pokemon world had to offer, but Leon didn't seem to feel the same way. welp, blogpost time. I'll spoiler it so people who don't give a shit can keep scrolling.
I mainly went to Vegas because the Las Vegas Open, which is the biggest convention for tabletop wargames was being held at the Rio, and I participated in the championship tournament for Warhammer 40k. Unfortunately, on the 4th of my 6 games, my biggest model had broken, so I dropped out. That was really my biggest disappointment, but I had fun nonetheless. I was crashing with a friend who had an apartment there, so I didn't have to stay at the decrepit hotel.
Other activities involved losing money at gambling (sorry, Dawn), firing guns at Battlefield Vegas, killing zombies in virtual reality, eating at Guy Fieri's burger restaurant and at Din Tai Fung, and visiting a bunch of the famous hotels on the strip, as well as the Atomic Testing Museum and the Omega Mart. I have a feeling I've forgotten one or two things.

In the movie "The Dark Knight Rises", Dr. Pavel's kidnapping serves as a crucial part of Bane's plan to destroy Gotham City. As a nuclear physicist, Dr. Pavel's expertise is used to help Bane and his accomplices build a nuclear device that they threaten to use to destroy the city. The character is depicted as being under duress and forced to work for Bane, and his role in the film highlights the urgency and danger of the situation facing Gotham City and its people.

Dr. Pavel's kidnapping and his role in Bane's plan also play into the larger themes of the movie, which revolve around the consequences of violence and the importance of hope in the face of adversity. Throughout the film, characters must grapple with the consequences of their actions, and the stakes are high as they work to prevent Bane's plan from coming to fruition. Ultimately, Dr. Pavel serves as a symbol of the power of knowledge and the dangers of its misuse, and his role in the film adds depth and complexity to the story.

It's worth noting that the character of Dr. Pavel is not a major player in the film, and his screen time is relatively limited. Nevertheless, he serves an important function within the narrative and helps to drive the action forward. By kidnapping Dr. Pavel and using his expertise to build a nuclear device, Bane underscores the threat he poses to Gotham City and the lengths he is willing to go to in order to achieve his goals. This makes Dr. Pavel's character an important part of the film, and helps to create a sense of tension and urgency that drives the story forward.

In conclusion, while Dr. Pavel may not be a prominent character in "The Dark Knight Rises", his role as a nuclear physicist kidnapped by Bane and used to help build a nuclear device is crucial to the film's story and themes. Overall, Dr. Pavel serves as an important part of the film, and helps to make "The Dark Knight Rises" a rich and complex story that is both thrilling and thought-provoking.

I firmly believe that it was probably originally that weird snow yeti thing or a female counterpart to the weird yeti. The development team probably loved it because it was based on a Kaiju they all thought was goofy and it stuck around for a while. And then through all of the cuts and deciding who to keep, somebody had a thing for this Pokémon which caused them to hang on to it but make it trade only after it became the female only design. They also gave it Psychic type to make it more of a counterpart to Mime, who is also trade only, then realized after the controversy they probably shouldn't have bothered at all. So it got the design change, it got the baby, and then they just sort of ignored it for the rest of time even replacing it with another Ice/Psychic Mime in Gen 8. What they really need to do with this Pokémon, IMO, it's just give it a evolution that's different enough people will just think about that thing all the time now. That way it can still exist and have its Gen 1 privilege + address power creep. But it also avoids the controversy because now everyone's worried about the interesting evolution that breathed new life into the concept and is actually competitively viable, sort of like what they did with Primeape

>>53174482
People forget that Generation 1 had hundreds upon hundreds of designs for monsters that pretty much all were based on pop culture before anything else. The final 151 that we got to a Western audience seem like they were based on generic RPG monsters and things like that, which some of them were, but they have far more influences from Japanese culture than we are aware of. Like a third of the fucking Pokémon in Gen 1 are just things from Dragon Quest or Ultraman, it's not hard to imagine the rest are also based on crap that we don't know very well here and that they are probably all each a hodgepodge of several ideas that would have been familiar to Gen Xer Japanese game devs in the early to mid '90s

I think Jynx being partly inspired by the yokai Yamanba would make sense. She was big in Japanese dance plays which explains the dance stuff in Jynx's Pokedex entries. She was a witch often connected with snow on the mountains which explains the Psychic/Ice typing. And she popularly looked like an ugly longhaired negress in Japanese media at the time (pic related from 1991) which explains Jynx's appearance. She even inspired some of that negroesque ganguro fashion later on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53174786
The gyaru fashion first started in the 70s having its peak between 1989-1999, Jynx's Japanese name (ルージュラ) is the same as a cosmetic brand popularly used by these girls, and both Jynx and a subcategory of this fashion are based on a yokai Yama-Uba or Yamamba, an old woman from the mountains in a red dress (due to blood in some stories) and golden or platinum hair.

For greater coincidence, Smochun has a haircut and a stylized body to that of the infant Kintaro, a legendary hero who was raised by a yama-uba.

I'm not saying that Jynx is inspired by this, just that both having a common source (Yama-Uba) it's normal for them to look alike.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>During a recent interview with Nintendo of Canada, the branch’s General Manager apologized for the buggy nature of Pokemon Scarlet & Violet and promised improvements are on their way.

>Pokemon Scarlet & Violet’s launch was less than spectacular despite selling ten million copies three days into its lifespan. That’s because the game’s massive success wasn’t the only thing that left players dumbfounded.

>Bugs, glitches, and performance issues were as abundant as Pokemon in the Paldea region during its first week on shelves. Player models contorted, trainers fell through holes in the map, and countless hours of progress were lost to crashes and performance issues.

>The Pokemon Company has since acknowledged the issues and plans to release an update near the end of February 2023. And in an interview with Post Arcade, Nintendo of Canada GM Susan Pennefather addressed the current state of Pokemon Scarlet & Violet.

>During the interview, Post Arcade asked Susan Pennefather what Nintendo had learned from Pokemon Scarlet & Violet’s rocky launch.

>Pennefather answered, “You know, we absolutely apologize. Because it is so important to give players a positive experience with our games, and when this doesn’t happen, we do take it very much to heart.”

>She continued with a promise, “What I can say is the feedback from players has absolutely been taken very seriously. And we are working on improvements to these games.”

>This is already believed to be the case, as in mid-January 2023, Serebii reported that the long-awaited version 1.2 update would be released in late February. It promises various bug fixes as well as “added functionality.”

>Regardless, it’s nice to have a formal apology from a branch of Nintendo and reassurance that the mysterious update is on its way.

Essentially, you are trying to get as much PMUP on her before she dishes out her Fly using Metronome. She has Super Powered 5, so her Fly WILL hit hard. (Although she needs accuracy buffs). If you run her off-type, all you need is Metronome.

That's just it though? Its RNG based, but Metronome is 2/3 special attacks except fissure. So you're gonna have a good time stacking PMUP. Her Drill Peck also does a lot of damage as well especially on ontype.

I probably wouldn't recommend it unless you like her, or you need a Physical Striker for Flying-types.

Look at the leaderboards for inspiration, it’s gauntlet so people inevitably have to start using F2P/non-limited pairs.

For Latias you want a debuffer that hits at least two stats per turn. Lucian and Janine/Ariados are good non-limited options, Kiawe could also work if you have another single debuffer to supplement him. May/Blaziken, not-Champion Iris and Serena/Greninja are easy mode clears.

For Uxie you want to use something that can burn/poison/paralyze reliably, plus a trapper.

Regirock you can just bonk it really hard with physical strikers, and maybe use units you can grid to disable defense debuffs on.

The battle system itself is fun, sort of the second try for triple battles, but you will see most of what the game has to offer (Battle Villa, Elite 4, Legendary Battle Gauntlets) in two to three months time, after which you are powering up your characters and occasionally spinning the slots for new ones to continue playing those same modes more effectively, though the specific battles do rotate. You can guarantee a time-limited character with enough free gems, so you just save until a real prize comes along. The special costumes and trainer lodge guests tend toward ladies, what with the female player characters having thrice the costumes the boys do, while Steven, N, Morty, and the Subway bros take a lot of the male real estate, but I don't have a ratio off the top of my head. The writing has its moments but is mostly fluff trivia, feels like a more focused version of the TV anime, what dating sim elements there are are very light.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some fun facts, because I'm bored:
Elesa is the only character with four different outfits to have never been paired with a Legendary/Mythical Pokémon.

Leaf is the only female main character to have less outfits than her male counterpart. This was also true with Hilda after Hilbert's Halloween costume, until she got her special costume with Diancie.

Sygna Suit Lysandre is the first male sync pair in nearly two months, since Champion Calem.

Lillie is the only character with four different outfits where none of her outfits are a Sygna Suit. Conversely, Cynthia is the only character with four different outfits where all of her alt outfits are Sygna Suits.

To this day, there are only two characters who have received alt outfits who are neither 5* nor story characters, those being Siebold and Whitney, with a nearly 3 year gap between their releases.

Ash is (to my knowledge) the only character to have voice lines mentioning his partner Pokémon's name.

The trainer moves of Bugsy (Scyther) and Sygna Suit Blue have the exact same effect.

>I guess fantasy stuff? You working on anything currently?
I have one story I'm working on lately about a witch fleeing the trials of late 1600s America, and jumping on the westward expansion bandwagon to get away (I'm fudging the dates a bit from historical realism). It's half a story about someone trying to live in peace and do the right thing when the demands of survival are so high, and half about how you can never really hide who you are no matter how far you run so it's better to just find a home that loves you back to grow in. It may sound a bit cringy when you lay it out like this, but I'm enjoying it.

I also basically always hafve DnD/PF writing going. Characters, campaigns, worldbuilding, this stuff never really ends and it stays a creative outlet for me when I'm running out of other ideas.

Is it mainly how much the box was printed, or are there other factors?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53166801

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53167091
It's based on lots of factors, but the most important ones based on what I've seen are the quantity of boxes printed by the company, and how worth it the chase cards are. A good example from recent sets is Evolving Cries, it's a mediocre set but since it has a lot of chase cards for collectors, it will keep going up in value.

To be honest this is actually good, because as long as you don't care about mainstream shit like Gluraks and whatnot, you can grab things you like relatively cheaply even years after they stop getting printed.

Even if you don’t care about monetary value all that much it’s a good thing; if you want to keep that Serena card you’ll never have to buy it as a single, if you don’t care about the Serena you can sell it for a good price and use the money to buy more cards.

As far as what to do next I would urge you to really do some research and figure out what you enjoy the most. If you just really want to keep up with modern and rip packs then find out which sets are in print and have cards you truly enjoy. That way you can focus on buying sets that you like rather than gambling on packs where you might not pull anything you enjoy at all.

If you want to be more efficient in collecting then you should start buying singles of the cards you want to collect. Search TCGPlayer/Cardmarket and eBay to get a feel for what good prices are. Set aside a reasonable amount of time each week to check prices and buy things when you feel they’re affordable and unlikely to drop in the future.

Cubone and Machop are around the same level, at least in the original.
Cubeone's STAB moves suffer both from low PP and unreliable accuracy.
The most difficult bosses until postgame are the three birds and Rayquaza - against all of which cubones stab does very little damage.
And no, it does not get Rock Slide in the original.
Machop does slightly more damage and more PP to work with, but gets absolutely giga-fucked by pretty much all bosses except Groudon.
Which one is worse honestly depends on the situation, but all in all they're about equally garbage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53179987
>Cubone at least has multihits, and a 2 hit ranged attack
In theory, you are correct.
In practice, there are some problems with that:
Cubone learns Bone Rush at Level 41. That's well into the postgame, so that doesn't help you with the parts of them game that both Cubone and Machop struggle the most with.
Bonemerang is learn upon Level 25. If you play through the game without grinding, you typically reach that around Magma Cavern/Sky Tower.
Sky Tower is particular is filled with Flying Types and Pokemon that have levitate, so it isn't nearly as useful as you might think. Also, the accuracy is terrible.

After Rayquaza, you can reliably farm gummies and TMs so the difference between the two becomes rather insignificant, at least in my experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53180059
Sometimes your starter is your least worst option post Rayquaza.
Most of them are gonna struggle, because the dungeons after Sky Tower pick up significantly in difficulty.
Most importantly, you absolutely need an anwer to Monster houses at that point. And barely any starters have that, since Earthquake is terribly unreliable. The only starter to have that is Charmander, since Charizard can learn Heatwave immediately (Problem being of course that you have to grind another 10 leveln on average, but basically every starter needs to grind lul).
I used to just go recruit Arcticuno immideately for that reason, since it come high level and with an excellent movepool that includes Powder Snow. Problem with that is or course its size. Your teams combined Size cannot exceed 6, and Articuno already has a size of 4, so you cannot use it to recruit most of the other big legendaries.
honestly, the best way to play the original rescue team ist probably to pick Charmandar as a starter along with something busted to carry you until postgame, then dump all your gummies into Charmandar all at once and solo the rest of the game with Charizard.

posts.com:
So, after what I'm pretty has at least been a 15 years since I have last seen Heroes, I finally rewatched it and watched it in subs too. I still feel the same way I did the last time I have seen it: loved it.
There are a few things I want to mention: the 3D surprisingly doesn't stick out like a sore thumb, that was something I was worried about on rewatch as it might've took me right out of the experience. I never realized how borderline useless Misty and Brock were in this film; if it were not for one scene late into the film, one could've removed them and the plot wouldn't change, this film, for all intents and purposes, was a film between Ash and Latias. I never realized Latias has a leitmotif, it being derived from the song "Search for the Girl," and it being first used when Ash meets Latias in her human disguise and again at the end when she runs up onto the dock to see Ash one last time. This film made me realized that Ash being Thunderbolt'd to save Latias wasn't his first time, he did that here when he jumped into Aerodactyl to save Latias and asked Pikachu to use Thunderbolt on the former while Ash was still on it. Final moment I want to mention, the credit song, "You're Not Alone," is lovely but I can't help but do a stretch, it feels like a song from Latias to Ash.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53169447
Haha, thank you for this! I am Norwegian and can give you my review on this after watching for a bit.

They are voiced by the same few VAs every single Norwegian dub of any every single animated show had back in the days. And I mean every single show. I suppose the market for Norwegian dub voice actors weren't the biggest, so these few voices more or less did every dub on TV.
I find it nostalgic but at the same time hearing Ash speak my language feels pretty weird. It sounds so over-the-top I can't help but laugh at times(and Ash is clearly voiced by someone 20+ years of age). When Latias reveals herself and Lorenzo comments "Hun må virkelig like denne unge mannen, gitt!"("She must really like this young man, geez"), it is delivered in a pretty hilarious way void of any emotion, but at the same time sounding like an old Norwegian sailor stereotype.
I really don't know how I would rate this, but I love that the dub exists regardless. This came out in DVD form with the box art being localized for Norwegian as well. Overall I don't think the quality is bad, I just don't have any reference to compare it to. Wholesome/10!

Thanks a million for this anon!
I am a swede, so the Norwegian dubs were on all the DVDs, and have always been an option on Netflix over here.
I really enjoy the flow and intonation of Norwegian, and as >>53169809 mentions Ash sounds like a proper man, which is a lot of fun to me. I always make sure to watch any movies I can a second time in Norwegian.
I have great respect for both the Swedish and Norwegian VAs since most of them have stayed with their respective characters through the entire series since day one. Most probably beacause they are, as anon also mentioned, the few bargain-bin voices who are in every animated show ever (also respect).
The Scandinavian dubs can be hard to find in the digital age of English, so this in particular is a great treat.
The best version of the M5 race song is the Danish one, though. So if one were a crazy autist, one would dance between the DVD dub tracks when that song comes on.

>>53170998
From what I have seen/heard around it's basically because the movie is a good movie, not just a good Pokemon movie but a good movie in general.
It's visuals are really good and nice to see (and have aged really well), the plot is nice and pretty interesting too and the characters and their interactions/relationships are compelling and fun to witness, especially when it comes to Ash and Latias who share what is probably one of the closest things to a romance plot the anime has had without being too in your face about it (it's sometimes described as a surprising "boy meets girl" story), and has a really emotional climax that makes you feel for the characters involved alongside a really sweet ending.
It's overall a really nice and compelling story to watch that has a lot of heart put into it and is enjoyable even after all these years.

Yes it does, I don't know who you think you're fooling when you're practically screaming to the skies that you never even try to use more pokemon like the rest of us so don't even pretend to.
If you actually played the games you'd know that pokemon's gameplay is centered around maximizing damage against the opponent while minimizing their damage on you. A lot of the gym leaders and especially the e4 and champion can be within 2 shot range against a lot of your mons, while also being likely to outspeed. What this means is that you need to figure out how to get yourself in a position where they're dealing little enough damage that you can actually keep up with them without burning all your items trying to keep your dudes alive. This is where the gameplay comes in. Sleep, paralysis, burn, freeze, confusion, infatuation, stat stages etc are all passive ways you can alter the dynamics of the battle to be more in your favor. These moves are actually super fucking useful when you can't mow down the enemy is 1-2 hits and making use of them to take out the enemy at a disadvantage is THE bread and butter of pokemon's gameplay. And THAT is why we're all laughing at you right fucking now. Because you don't understand this, and so obviously never will because to you needing to actually engage with the game to earn a win isn't worth it if there's a quicker option available. >What is Fanfiction/Write Thread? Isn’t it /vpwt/?
Much like Mystery Dungeon General /pmdg/, writefag threads named /vpwt/ are always cursed to die from inactivity, so we’ve had more luck with informal threads. So yes and no, same purpose as /vpwt/ but not cursed. Now, let’s get to the fanfic/writing part

>What are you writing currently?

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53154813
>What are you reading currently?
Just proofin' something non-fandom.

>What are you writing currently?
I got half of a chapter on my current WIP, which having been writer's blocked for a few years now will hopefully get over that hump.

>What’s your favorite kind of fic? (Recommendations?)
The kind that challenges its characters to deal with problems, not merely act out "being in the world of the IP" or "let's save the day" kinds of tropes.

>>Which Pokemon do you wish got featured more in stories?
I think that it's good that many species don't get featured much. There are so many kinds of pokemon that it makes sense that some simply don't inhabit places or exhibit behaviors that put it in the kinds of places where interesting fiction happens. The other side of this is that when a rarely featured pokemon appears, it needs to hit a home run and demonstrate what it uniquely has to offer a narrative while also showing that we should be happy not to see it too often. That preserves the mystique and gets the most mileage out of relatively untrodden paths.

>>Author QOTT: What’s one thing about creating a story you wish readers understood better?
That the author has no idea how what's written will be received. Scenes I felt were kinda dull connectors have stolen spotlights and bits I thought were profound have fallen flat. So while compliments on a work as a whole are well appreciated, it's comments on the individual bits that hit or missed that can provide actionable feedback letting the author develop a second-person perspective on how the piece looks to a reader on the other side of the screen.

posts.name: Purple Blaziken
posts.com:
>>53155025
Exactly what you describe in terms of needing to justify the usage of niche species in order to fairly give them a spotlight is what I’m going for in my Mystery Dungeon story. It’s a long story with a big world, so I have a lot in mind to showcase some underloved Pokemon without feeling like they’re being forced into relevance. That’s what I always loved about playing the Mystery Dungeon series and it’s something I’m strongly trying to carry over into my own take on the concept. For example, Diglett or Bidoof or Loudred are not Pokemon I ever would’ve thought could make for entertaining/interesting characters until I saw them in action in Mystery Dungeon. I’d love readers to have that same feeling, that “Aha!” moment that allows them to see a shitmon/obscure pick in a new light.

I also totally love your answer for the QOTT, I feel like that’s something that goes across all entertainment media: painters, musicians, actors, writers; often times it’s the work we expect to hit hard that gets glanced over and the work that we second guess that lands a home run with the audiences. I agree with your note on specific feedback, but think an equally valid way forward (that you could totally do in conjunction) would be to always keep your stories fresh and diverse in terms of emotion, word choice, structure, plot, character, etc; feeling like I’m reading the same chapter twice in a row is my worst feeling as a reader, so it’s my worst fear as an author, I don’t think you should ever let a story stagnate. You can still adjust to your successes and losses and tell a perfectly fluid story without allowing style or standards to stagnate.

Best of luck on clearing your block, you got it!

I'm the one that went on the several post critique of it in that thread. I have no problem with the author taking an immature tone, or that he is trying to have fun with it. I have a personal distaste for what the popular group of PMD readers considers 'fun', which turns me off of a clearly targeted work such as that one. It holds all the ingredients to become popular, but I don't think it will be something that I personally will consider well-written. It's not offensive in that sense, either, so it's not really worth getting heated about. At the very least it's not a novelization.

I've dabbled with something like that, though not for pokemon in particular. As far as I discovered in my brief stint into that sort of thing, it's rather important that you don't think of the story as just a one-to-one extension of exactly what happened in the game. It's difficult to steer away from an outright novelization, but altering in-game and mechanical events to spin your own story/character seems to work out the best. Just off the top of my head, you could write a struggling party member with shit stats or nature as having a completely different made-up problem which then creates a conflict in the story. You'd also probably play the game incrementally with progressing your writing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53168964
I already did. I was the pmd thread critique. I think that your descriptions are weak because you rely too heavily on adverbs and by applying adjectives rather than exploring more interesting ways to convey imagery, as well as falling into telling behavior. But I'll elaborate on that if I must. Let's take something from the second chapter.

>“Buddy, you better watch your mouth,” Zangoose grows super serious, clearly offended and now speaking in a tone that’s making me feel increasingly unsafe.

"Grows super serious" is a telling statement, which is always a weaker alternative to applying context. As is the continuation stating that he's "clearly offended" and "making [Nathan] feel unsafe". This is simply a weak way to demonstrate something that was already given to the reader if only based on what Zangoose had already said. It's pretty clear that he's offended already, and that the Natu is in a precarious position to be pissing people off, but I understand that you wanted to express the change of tone and Nathan's fear. Were I to write out the same thing myself, it'd probably be a bit something like:

>"Buddy, you better watch your mouth," Zangoose snapped. I wince at the tone of his voice, trying to make myself small in my sling, but he continued to shout.

It's maybe not the best, or even what you wanted out of that sentence, but it's not mincing any words. It has a speech tag that assists the sudden shift in tone, a physical reaction from Nathan that denotes his mental state and provides physical imagery, and a way to denote that Zangoose is going to continue speaking.

It's things like that you can improve on with your prose. It should go without saying that having sentences like "Adjacent to this is a gently flowing river of crystal clear freshwater," can be a road bump in the reader's pacing and generally just rambles on implicit details to what you already describe as a vital, life-giving water source.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53169385
Agreed. In addition to the meme baggage of "super serious" (evoking memories of the South Park running gag with Al Gore saying "super cereal" instead as a malaprop) it's also evocative of childish and adolescent speech patterns that use adjectives for superlative emphasis.

The problem with the original line, and what can be improved in Anon's suggestion, is that there is an unexploited opportunity (as Anon mentions) to SHOW Zangoose's emotional transition rather than TELL it after the fact. This needs to be done first, because it colors the spoken part. As originally written—some sort of dialog tag with present tense narration that's jumping out of POV (I presume this is narrator-as-protagonist and doing kind of a stream of consciousness thing to justify present tense) awkwardly for the sake of presuming something—it's closer to a script, which isn't disallowed, but it's easy to get into a habit of just writing the spoken lines and tagging, forgetting that when we shift attention we must refresh the portrayal.

Ex.

(MC says something stupid.)

Zangoose's ears twitched and his eyes narrowed. He squared up his posture and sucked a sharp breath while the fur across his shoulders stood on end. "Buddy," he growled deeply, "you'd better watch your mouth." He leaned in, and I felt so threatened I couldn't help but to sink into my sling, feeling small and needy of protection.

>river thing
This is a fault of overloading one sentence. Long sentences can be cool, but they still need to be about one thing.

"Adjacent to this is a gently flowing river. Its waters are fresh, safe to drink, and crystal clear."

Two sentences cover two separate things—the river as a waterway and the water that flows in said waterway—and allows both to be better served without truly reducing the amount of described detail. Indeed, I've increased it, but it's easier to read because it's following an introduction/description pattern rather than wadding the whole thing up.

>>53155636
Sc 1 - I'm reminded of children's books I read long ago. I would not consider this a good thing.

Sc 2/3 - Were it not for my decision to give the entirety of the first chapter a read-through I would have stopped reading here. Cliche, rote, tired, - take your pick, whatever you like, they are all an accurate summary of these two scenes. Wholly unnecessary and baffling in their inclusion unless the aim is to heap still more young adult fiction onto the already burgeoning pile that exists with little regard for the appetite the audience has for higher lit. Aim for the smaller pile - everyone will be happier for it.

It is not lost on me this is fan fiction, but [good] fan fiction should make you forget that.

Sc 4 - See above.

Sc 5 - My attention unravels.

You show things that aren't necessary, and tell things that are. The overall construction of the work makes it abundantly clear that whoever is penning the prose knows how to write, but only in one specific way, and that way is long past its service-by date.

That's my best attempt at being succinct, because I don't want to spend an hour taking a fine-toothed comb to this. I will instead offer up a suggestion: Read Nisioisin. I feel the author will likely give you plenty of ideas and techniques to chew on that you could integrate into the parts of the work. He's character-focused and dialogue heavy, so he's not a good source for building up skills when it comes to exposition, but there are plenty of authors that do that as is.

Side note: Really, there's no need to run the PMD introduction gauntlet (sc. 2/3). It is exists for and in service of the gameplay, and it has no business being in a piece of prose when what it establishes could be better handled in scenes dedicated to showing what the questions try to illustrate. This is a common pitfall that dozens and dozens of PMD writers fall victim to and it is confusing to me every single time to find yet another body blinking up at me from the hole.

posts.name: Purple Blaziken
posts.com:
>>53171732
Ah, I appreciate the correction and at risk of sounding dumb I'd like to say that *now* I understand what you mean. I've already attempted to adapt to the complaints on imagery and clunky sentence structure in the upcoming 3rd chapter, I'm thinking it'll probably be worthwhile to do a revision of the first two chapters accordingly. From what I can gather, the actual events of the first two chapters aren't the problem, just the way which they're conveyed and how they get info across, which I think is definitely workable. Hopefully I can get some of the same anons to give the revised versions a go when I write them so that I know how things stack up compared to their first read, but ultimately it's a decision that'll be beneficial to all readers.

In terms of target audience, I've been very vocal that I'm writing for all ages, I don't want kids to stumble across it and either get scarred for life or not be able to comprehend what they're reading, I think Pokemon is a series that unites and entertains people of all ages with a skew towards children, and so at least for my inaugural fanfiction I'd like to maintain that same tone. I know not everyone, especially on this board, wants to read a YA fanfic, but that's the series you're playing, it's the kind of content the games invite. Although at this point enough people have commented on my childrens fiction career and made insinuations about my overall writing ability that I'm feeling inclined to write an adult Pokemon fic to show that I'm not talking out of my ass when I say that TNP is stylized. Is that something people would give a try?

Nathan is 10-13. He's smart but he's gullible. He's been around the block, but he doesn't have worldly experience, he's a bit of a nerd dependent on someone to strongly guide me. Ultimately this is the start of a long story, I'm not gonna start out with a brave and seasoned hero, that's a journey the audience will get to experience for themselves.

Slight correction, I haven't been published for 15+ years, I've been coming up with ideas for this story for 15+ years, I've only been published around 1/3 of that time (and I've only been actually writing this story for like a week).

Also, when Nathan first confers with the Guiding Spirit and he's thinking of that argument from his home universe, the Spirit says
>It is a memory of another time, but now you are here. You may recall bits and pieces from that place, but it’s best to focus on where you are now.
His memories are spotty; certain sensations, like seeing a Pokémon he recognizes or being reminded of volcanoes might bring back memories of home. The purpose of the reminder line from the Spirit is to say that it's giving him a freebie; he'll have to go through the world in order to jog his memories, but she let him remember his name since he 'passed' the quiz. While it is included in tribute to the games, his amnesia is central to both the development of the plot and his overall character, like the Personality Quiz I didn't include it just to include it, I found ways to make them meaningfully woven into the plot.

>>53159234
Not how it works, each player spawns his own Pokemon.
It's why the guide multiple times says to be far apart, because if scarlet player is near violet player, violet player will only render 5 spawns max so he gets 3 violet paradox, then the scarlet near him spawns 2 scarlet paradoxes and scarlet sees 3 violet.
Instead of getting 10 max spawns, 10 shiny rolls, you're only getting 5.
The scarlet paradoxes belong and were spawned by the scarlet player, so they have the effects of the scarlet player while the violet player paradoxes has violet player effects.


So if violet eats teensy 3 and scarlet eats humong 3, violet gets 3 teensy spawns and the other 2 scarlet paradox will be humongo

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53166852
>>53166909
OK I think I finally did the math right. The trick is that prize cards are only laid AFTER your first set of cards.

With 4 of these in your deck, on turn 1 you have a 49% chance of drawing at least one (before prize cards are laid).
If you go second, assuming none in the prize cards, you have a 58% chance of drawing at least one. With a Professor's Research, that the chance goes pretty much guaranteed.

I needed to try something and I've been wanting to try out a rocket-locke for a while, so I may start out a run next weekend if I finish Dead Space 2 by then.

The basics is that I can steal any pokemon from the trainer I battle first in an area (really interesting because if you can avoid trainers you have some control over the potential pools depending on trainer types). Also, to compensate for missing catches due to some areas having no trainers, I will allow myself to try capturing each gym's leader last pokemon.

But I need help deciding how to implement a dupes clause. I'm thinking that it only comes into play when the trainer I choose happens to only be carrying one single mon I already have. Because otherwise, if I'm against a trainer with 3 mons for example, and I skip the first 2 to fish for something better only to get a dupe, it just doesn't feel fair that I get to retry with another trainer: I chose to risk it and I should face the consequences.

Thoughts?

Empoleon
Misdreavus
Rotom (in Platinum)
Gengar
Roserade
Infernape (if you're desperate)
Golduck
Espeon

Not every single one of those is stellar, and for some you would rather use their coverage instead of choice (like Misdreavus or Gengar), but they're useable

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53148721
NTA but I always see people talk about how good Misdreavus is, are they really good?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53149318
I would say so. They lack the setup moves in Sinnoh that make some competitive sets great (Nasty Plot is HGSS tutor only, Calm Mind is Battle Frontier only), but they have good Speed and Sp. Atk, and work as a great TM dump (Shadow Ball, Thunderbolt, Psychic, Dark Pulse), which is the sort of coverage you would want for a Specs user in DPP

Downsides are the low encounter rate (just Eterna Forest and Lost Tower), Pearl exclusive and that Dusk Stone takes a bit to show up, but it's a solid choice considering the other encounters on those areas aren't as great except for Gastly

Also, Dusk Stone in HGSS is post-game only, which makes them a lot less useful in those games

For those of you who remember (probably no one), on my last attempt Skyla wrecked in my shit. So i was pretty fucking scared going into it. Especially with 2 Fire Types. Here's what happened....

>Skyla.
I lead off with my newest lad, Quirrel the Escavalier. Acrobatics from Swoobat doesn't do much damage. About 1/3rd. X-Scissor does 95%. Swoobat heals and Quirrel goes for another X. After taking another Acrobatics, Quirrel finishes Swoobat off.

Out comes Swanna. Not my ideal situation since the strat I cooked up required Skarm to come out. No matter, I had a back-up! I send out Austin on an Air Slash. I let Austin use Light Screen while Swanna goes for another Air Slash, activating my Sitrus. Austin T-waves and gets hit with a crit Bubblebeam, leaving him on 4. hp.(*)

I send out Twoona on another Bubblebeam. Twoona plucks away Swanna's Sitrus. I send in Embuppy on the last turn of Light Screen and he takes an Air Slash extremely well. I pray to RNGsus and Emb manages to kill Swanna with Thunder Fang.

Skarm comes out last and I send in Flambill to kill it. Lava Plume leaves Skarm on a sliver, but due to Flame Body burning Skarm, it dies in 2 turns anyway.

* Another stroke of luck on my end. Going up to Skyla I had Austin hold lefties, decided to switch for a Sitrus instead since my original plan was letting Twoona set up Tail Wind on Skarm, using pluck/faint attack to ruin sturdy and finish with Tail Winded Embuppy, so Twoona having lefties would've worked better.

You guys might think overstragetizing is robbing the fun, but coming up with strats is my favorite bit of a locke.

Never played Platinum. How does it stack up to SP?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53170527
Not that anon but both games have their benefits. Platinum has more Sinnoh pokemon available (early Rotom, evolution items like Razor Fang and Reaper Cloth in the main game) as well as better teams in terms of pokemon.
BDSP has modern Pokemon features like Fairy type, better learnsets, and crit captures as well as quality of life features like HMs being tied to the Poketch and good TMs being easily available. However it misses out on Platinum's additions like a handful pokemon and items not being available till post game and updated teams. But in exchange, the Elite Four is substantially more challenging and the post game buffs up rematch teams and introduces new fights against Dawn/Lucas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Weirdest Drayden fight ever.

>Drayden
I lead with Tryvern the Flygon. The strategy was ride or die AKA batshit retarded. Banking on Drayden to always press the SE button or DD up with Tryvern spamming Dragon Tail.

It immediately went sideways with Druddigon using Slash instead. And Tryvern managing to Dragon Tail out Druddigon for HAXORUS. Now here is the thing. Dragon Tail has -6 priority. I THOUGHT that if both mons have -6 priority, the speediest one should go first, right? I dumped all my Carbos on Tryvern. Flygon is faster than Haxorus.

Yet Haxorus still outsped with his Dragon Tail killing Tryvern immediately.

I send in Austin as a sacrifice. T-Wave against Dragon Dance. Reflect against Full paralysis. Then the unthinkable happens.

Austin, the smug fucker who thinks he is hot shit, manages to land all 3 Blizzards in a row against a Haxorus that uses nothing but Dragon Dance, thereby soloing Haxorus. That's right. My -defense Audino solo'd Haxorus.

Druddigon came in and Austin immediately misses Blizzard and gets Dragon Tailed out. For the mon I wanted to go into anyway, Quirrel. Quirrel dispatches the already weakened Drud with an Iron Head. Flygon comes in, but because Quirrel can't be crit, Quirrel manages to two shot the fucker with 2 X-Scissors while living on 47hp.

Funny thing was that if Tryv managed to survive, he'd replace Austin. Now I feel obligated to keep the pink fucker on.

>>53175551
alright, here's my attempt
I released my starter because I haven't done a Nuzlocke without a starter in a while and wanted to change it up (it was Oshawott).

My first two encounters were a pair of level 4 male Patrats, so I decided that they were brothers and began brainstorming. Seeing as they both had similar natures (Naughty/Likes to Run and Lonely/Thoroughly Cunning) I thought that they'd be a pair of NYC-style conmen constantly on the run. Their next destination was probably Driftveil city, since that's where all the rich miners lived, and the two had been stuck in Nuvema due to a freak flood that took them there from Route 17.

Goggles was the initial MVP, guiding his younger brother through roads only he'd been down, working mostly alone even up to the Dreamyard. While there the pair reluctantly picked up Mittens just to have a chance against Cilan's team, who'd spotted them doing shady shit with Dusk Ball Guy, and was about to call the police. Goggles convinced the gym leader team that they should just fight it out instead, and after Cilan's Pansage agreed the three went to train.
During this training, Goggles got into a grudge match with an old Patrat from his pack, and went down from a crit after taunting it one time too many, prompting Snorkel to rush to the PC.
Unfortunately, he couldn't save Goggles, and upon exiting the center he was greeted with Cheren's Snivy, who'd *also* seen the pair doing dumb shit and challenged them to a battle because the snake found their activities personally offensive due to how "dishonorable" they were. Snorkel accepted without thinking, and had nearly won the thing when Snivy struck him down with a Vine Whip. Mittens finished the fight, but-

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53176845
(In-story) Snorkel remained in critical condition, unable to fight. Mittens had to practically drag him to train at the Dreamyard, where the pair met Pillow. Pillow was mainly attracted to the pair due to Snorkel's intense dreams, and she began to form a relationship with him to get easier access to said dreams. However, she and Snorkel began actually growing close, and Snorkel even took it upon himself to tell her some things about himself that he felt she might like. The pair grew closer and closer, practically becoming friends by the time they reached the Daycare, before Snorkel passed on while Pillow and Mittens toured the place.

(In-game) He actually just died to Cheren, but I misremembered while writing this whole thing and thought he'd died after him. Therefore, he and Pillow were close. Even though they never really fought on the same team lol.

After Snorkel's passing, Mittens and Pillow felt respectively aimless. Pillow grew bitter and wanted to leave, but Mittens had been genuinely affected by Snorkel's conman rhetoric and wanted to continue forth to Driftveil both to see what it was like (since he'd never been) and to make Snorkel proud. He made Pillow stay with him to do so, and she never let him hear the end of it.

The pair continued on, recruiting Hairdo and Hannah simply through Mittens telling them his idea of Snorkel's story, eventually reaching Nacrene. While there they paid witness to a rally regarding Pokemon rights, lead by a pair of Beeheyem and their Braviary leader, stating that humans were slaveholders and outright enemies of Poke-kind. The trio were only noticed due to the massive crowd surrounding them- which happened to include a rather enthusiastic Timburr, unaware of exactly what they were preaching (he was just there for the company).

Said Timburr seemed equally-as eager to join our trio once he spotted them- for reasons currently unknown. *So* eager that he wouldn't let them leave without him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53176913
Soon after they just resolved to bring him, much to the dismay of Pillow, and said Timburr was ecstatic.

Unfortunately, he was also stubborn about fighting the strongest Pokemon in every area he visited, *single-handedly.* Mittens managed to get him to compromise and allow help if he was struggling, but the Pansear still couldn't talk Tea Burr out of it.

Tea Burr also headed straight to Pinwheel to begin training to fight Lenora, whom he'd been trying to beat for ages by that point. Unwilling to let him go alone, Hannah followed suit, leading to the rest of the team *also* training.

During that training, Mittens was hit a little too hard by a Munna whom Pillow had picked a fight with, leading to his death.
Such a fall obviously caused rifts in the team, but none were hit harder than Pillow- who not only thought this was entirely her fault, but had now grown to see Mittens as an inevitability and a part of her life who'd always just *be* there.
She reluctantly took up the mantle of team leader and instructed everyone to keep training.

So that's where we are now- everyone is training, still kind of a mess, and trying to both beat Lenora and get to Driftveil.

Talking ooc- I realize this is kind of a mess and a massive dump of boring info. I wrote a lot of it very late at night yesterday and haven't had time to organize it, so most of this is not only ad-libbed but "2am-on-two-hours-of-sleep" adlibbed haha. I'm admittedly not sure if i'll beat Lenora at all since the level gap between her team's strongest and mine is currently massive (14 to 20, jesus) but I'm willing to grind and might even try for a Gurdurr before attempting anything. Anyways, struggling has been fun, as has writing this melodramatic stuff lol. Hopefully someone else has fun reading this too.

posts.com:
back to the story...
After the Gym battle, Tea Burr and Hairdo were both fired up. Tea Burr was insistent on hitting the next gym right away- Hairdo was simply happy to support him, especially if it meant that Hairdo got stronger in the process. Hannah was just happy to be there, and Pillow... reluctantly obliged. What else did she have to do, anyways?

Just as the group were exiting the museum, however, Pillow spotted (who seemed to be) Snorkel... stealing the skull of a Dragonite skeleton! She gave chase, caught too off-guard by the imagery to question it, with her team following soon after.

The Patrat brought them to Pinwheel Forest before vanishing into the woods, unable to be seen as the quartet continued further. The woods began getting darker and darker, more and more labyrinthian... and bam!
Eventually, the group was jumped by an aggressive Venipede, gunning straight for Pillow!
Hairdo caught the thing just in time, saving the Munna with a quick Air Cutter, earning her thanks in the process.
And even more thanks were to be given, as Pillow found a timid Sewaddle shaking where the Venipede once stood.

The next few minutes consisted of her blubbering gratitudes to the group, personally shaking each mon's hand (and Hannah's foot), before taking one look at Hairdo and realizing she was probably safer with Pillow.

Too tired to object to the Sewaddle tagging along, Pillow and her gang continued moving through the forest, with Sylvia insisting on taking out every opponent in their way as thanks... even after she evolved.

Walrien ended up being a perfect wall against Kingdra.

I was REALLY wanting to lead with Castform, but I couldn't risk him getting infatuated while setting up the sun, so I just went with Sceptile to take out Luvdisc and Sealeo. But then came the Kingdra.

I went into Walrien and attempted to Encore it into Double Team, but ofc it missed. Then I tried hitting it with Blizzards, but ofc it missed multiple times, eventually hitting it hard. I swapped to Absol during his healing turn to initiate my wacky strat, Perish Song force switch. It worked and was able to take out the Whiscash he brought in, but out came the Kingdra again.

This time however I was able to successfully encore him into Double Team, so I switched into my Guts boosted Swellow to hit some Aerial Aces, but encore wore soon so I had to do multiple switches to get Absol back in safely (and thankfully with no confusion) to Perish Song once again. During the perish counter wait, I set up Hail for chip damage.

Finally, I switch into Manectric to take out the Crawdaunt, and when his Kingdra came out once more, I decided to risk it and hit a Thunderbolt, which thankfully killed.

Sorry for the long post, but this battle was pretty nutty. It's funny this is the second time I used Perish Song against Kingdra, earlier I did so against Clair in Crystal, but her AI is predictable so I was able to take it out with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53161862
>Give it +10pts in SpAtt, bringing BST to 530 and SpAtt to 110
>Buff Illuminate so that it increases your Accuracy +2 each time you use a "light" move (happens before the attack goes off) and each time you are hit with a Dark move (happens after damage). This way there's a specific set up condition that isn't as simple as switching in. You reap the benefit for setting it up but it also means that people just can't send in this Pokémon and start spammimg Blizzard. Light moves would be moves like Dazzling Gleam, a lot of the Beam moves, etc.
>Replace Analytic with Hydration or Regenerator. Either makes way more sense and neither takes away from it also having Natural Cure as well
>Keep Meteor Beam and Flip Turn in its base moveset (they were cut from BDSP). It already learns a lot of really good offensive moves, but I would also give it access to Energy Ball, Whirlpool, Chilling Water, Acid Spray and Stored Power. I'm going to assume it would also get Tera Blast and Ice Spinner, even if the second is kinda pointless.
>Give it back a lot of the status moves it lost in Gen 8: Swagger, Psych Up, Confide, Reflect Type, Camouflage, Toxic and Spotlight. It already has Cosmic Power, but let's give it Acupressure and Growth too. It has such a wide move pool that I don't want it to feel overpowered if it's going to get Accuracy boosts on top of access to Nasty Plot or CM. Acupressure makes sense because it's a sea star, and I feel like Growth would be an interesting gimmicky setup move that does make sense on it. I also really want it to have Autotomize and Coil, because it's a goddamn sea star. Why wouldn't it be able to cut off a limb or curl up its body? Both would be super gimmicky as well but fun set up moves nonetheless

All right, how did I do? I'm already picturing a Doubles set that uses something like Dazzling Gleam, Hydro Pump, Thunder and Blizzard with Illuminate and holding a Weakness Policy w an ally using Brutal Swing

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

posts.com:
Previous thread: >>53145518

>What is this?
Part four of the ongoing saga of taking terrible MS Paint pics, ingame screenshots, and memes, and running them through Stable Diffusion/Novel AI to see what happens.
>What is this not?
This is not political theatre. Always report starving artists. Hide posts from starving artists. Do not reply to starving artists. If you are a starving artist, take it up with >>>/g/.
>How can I participate?
All you need to do is post a COLORED image that you want transmogrified. The AI will not color it in for you, or it will do a poor job doing so. Adding a description helps us gear the tagging process towards your specific fetis--tastes. Towards your tastes.
>But what if I can't doodle in Paint?
That's what the AI is for. Talent is optional, fun is mandatory.
>What program are you using?
I use a local Stable Diffusion setup. The real heavylifter in these threads uses NovelAI's $25 subscription service. I'm just second fiddle.
>Can I generate images too?
I don't know, can you? https://rentry.org/voldy
https://docs.novelai.net/
Remember that the real art is the cringe we felt along the way.

posts.com:
>>53157078
It’s definitely looking a lot better! Be careful with how many tags you’re using at a time—if there are too many details competing for the AI’s attention, the end result becomes muddled and confused. Put another way, each tag you type in is telling the AI “pay attention to this.” The AI will assume a character is wearing pants unless you specify otherwise, so it’s best to leave that detail to the AI’s imagination—insofar—if there are more important things to focus on. Likewise, requesting too many sample images to study will also result in the finished product becoming “overbaked.”
However, there is, in my experience, no upper limits on how many tags you can put in the Negative prompts—use this to your advantage by denying anything like “ugly, poorly-drawn, low quality, poorly-drawn hands, mutated limbs, bad anatomy,” and so on. Telling the AI what you don’t want to see is in many ways more important than telling it what you DO want to see. You see?

4th anon here, I’m not saying it’s invalid criticism, I’m just saying it’s disingenuous that OP frames it like a SV issue and not a series issue that has festered as technological and environmental standards for games have progressed. If this thread was designed to critique the entire series’ location naming conventions I’d be on board, but as is it’s trying to genwar something that’s present in every game which is gay. It should have always been different, but it wasn’t, and SV doing the same thing with a different name does not constitute the start of a new issue, rather it highlights the antiquated presence of a lingering one.

These are called goofs or errors, they're not a big deal to normal people and only autists hyper fixate on them. For example, the autistic creator of the anime has a boner for inserting real animals into the series and has said so in numerous interviews despite being told by the actual creator of the entire franchise that, No, animals do not exist in the Pokemon world, Pokemon are the animals.

By going down this path you all are failing to understand the real point of Pokemon, that it is meant to make the real world seem magical again, but taking real things like bugs, plants, animals, and even inanimate objects like magnets, and making them into fantastical versions of themselves, allowing you to see the world through childlike eyes once again. If there were real animals in addition to Pidgeys and Rockruffs and Spoinks, then that entire tactic would fall apart, as people would stop seeing Pokemon as a recontextualization of reality and would instead be something completely abstract and meaningless like Digimon.

The reason DIgimon failed is because the creatures in that are literally supposed to be lines of code in a computer, they represent nothing, they say nothing about anything. While Pokemon like Pickachu and Ratata, and Growlithe all represent actual pets people have had, they are imbued with inherent meaning and personality. You're trying to turn Pokemon into something soulless by saying actual animals exist alongside them. The Pokemon are the animals, not something else.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53163422
CP too low to be useful in PVE or ML. The increased damage dealt and received doesn't mesh well with how Registeel works in GL and UL (i.e., a bulky Pokemon that can quickly charge up to charge moves that otherwise cost too much for massive damage/shield pressure - the increase damage dealt is excessive for the charge moves and the increase damage taken goes against its tank role). It is still Registeel so it isn't terrible, but with the normal version out there at the moment I would prioritize getting it.

Take that with a grain of salt though, I struggle to get to Veteran.
